channel.title: B-Team
channel.description: Our Blogg for Founders and Coders

item.title: learnyouNode
item.description: We all had lots of fun tackling the exercises in learnyouNode, a Node.js training package which is aimed at experienced coders with broad javascript skills - just like us!! Back in the real world we all realised by the start of the second day that our scattergun approach to learning from scratch wasn’t going to cut it and some didacticism was required from a reluctant Dan. It was a pleasant change of pace working through the problems individually for an hour and then writing the solutions from scratch collaboratively. While it took a bit longer than expected we came out with a firmer grasp of javascript as well as a foundation in Node, new weapons in our assault on these recalcitrant machines!

item.title: Barrys last day
item.description:
Barry has gone, long live Barry!

Unfortunately, our friend Barry is leaving us. He will be missed! Although we are sad to be loosing him we can take comfort in the knowledge that Barry’s positive attitude, hard work and calming influence has found a good home in the GLA, where he will be tackling the ever important issue of London air quality.

Barry has his dream job, the GLA have their best man; some things are meant to be.

Good luck Barry!

item.title: Guardian widget presentation
item.description:
Just a smidge of extra pressure came to bear yesterday as the teams had to present their week two project a day early and to a particularly daunting audience. Stephan Fowler is a Senior Developer at Guardian News & Media and a very canny customer, and given that the project is actually a recruitment test for the Guardian he’s seen it executed by some of the best coders in the country. Team GetYourCodeOn blew us all away with the first presentation, Stefan was gobsmacked and struggled to find a constructive criticism!

When our time came Besart went toe to toe with the pro and ably held his own in a tense standoff over the niceties of Jquery loops! Here's a soundbite from a bowled-over Mr. Fowler:

item.title: The BBC API challenge
item.description:
On the BBC

  • Uk-news
  • Football
  • Travel

        Dude there's no javascript

item.title: Day three
item.description: It’s day three and we’ve learnt quite a lot of quite a little. From that, understand we’ve learnt the hard way, battling tooth and claw through misunderstanding, muddle and mistake to gain a fairly deep understanding of a few basic tools.

item.title: Liquid template in Jekyll
item.description:
Hi guys! Today I want to show you some jekyll! Basically I wanted that my posts page (all of them, possibly automatically) looked like the right one, from the forbes.com website.

To make this happened I used Jekeyll. Jekyll uses a liquid template engine, which basically helps you not writing the same code again and again.

From here on I take from grant that you are a bit familiar with liquid template engine, if this is not the case, I recommend to have a look at this short guide.

There are two types of markup in liquid:

  • Logic tags: These are conditional liquid statements. They are the statement that tells the code what to do.
  • Output tags: these tags display the liquid found between it. You can also use filters to change the output returned

First I created 4 nominative file in _include directory. I called them besart.html, barry.html, izaak.html and brian.html.

Than implement the following code in post.html

(% if page.author == "Besart" %}
   (% include besart.html %}
  (% endif %}

  (% if page.author == "Barry" %}
   (% include barry.html %}
  (% endif %}

At this point however I had to create a meta data called ‘author: authorName’. Which will be inherited first in post then in page.

item.title: Development area using Github pages.
item.description:
Below is a step-by-step guide about how to set up a development area in Nitrous.io using Github pages ..

1.Look at what you can do .. firstly set-up a Github (public) account and create a repository (bunch of files where you can store the docs/content for your website..). In this example we set-up a repository called ‘ettore90/blog’ for our web content.

2.The folders in your newly created Github repository will look something like this below..

3.Once your Github repository has been created you can ‘clone’ (copy+paste) the repository folders/files into the Nitrous development area by copying your Gitbub repository url, easy’huh :)

4.Now would be a good time to create an account/profile in Nitrous.io. Once in Nitrous click on the ‘new box’ tab and then click the ‘create box’ tab (see example below)

5.You’ll know your in your development area when you see the page below the most important part in this step is getting familar with the command-line, this is where you will clone (cut+paste) your Github repository in effect creating a copy of your website files.. Please type in the command-line git clone “github url” and hit return!

6.Enjoy building your webiste in your own ‘dev’ area .. :) but read step 7 first!

7.In the example above we are using Jekyll to develop our website, thats a whole other tutorial!!
